JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, MAY 24, 1957

61ST YEAR

miEBNID

June Week Festivities Harvard's Pusey To Speak
To Close Out Year At Graduation Exercises
June Week will begin this year on Tuesday, June 4,
with the Senior Prom at the Alcazar.
The orchestra of Ralph Marlene, who won the Senior
Class poll for the Prom dance, will be featured. The dance
will be from 9-1 and set-ups will be sold, stated Mitgang.
As decided earlier in the year, the Alcazar will allow drinking at the Prom.
The Bull Roast will be held on Wednesday, June 5,
at Bowley's Resort from noon to 10 pm. Beer, bull,

bathing and the Pier Five Jazz
Band will be featured. On the
following day the Sports Dance,
headlining The Four Lads and
the Boyd Raeburn Orchestra,
Will take place at the Dixie Ballroom. The Four Lads will not
only perform during intermission, but will sing several times
during the dancing.
A formal event for seniors
only, the Senior Banquet and
Dance, will be held June 8. June
Week Chairman Bob Mitgang
said, "The Banquet will begin
at 6 P. M:and Dr. Milton Eisenhower will speak." He added,"It
Will break up in time to bring
back dates for the dancing,
Which will last from 9-1. Both
the Banquet and Dance will be
formal." Strip tickets to June Week
events are selling in Levering
Hall at $13.00 to undergraduates
and at $11.50 to seniors. By taking advantage of the strip tickets, seniors may save as much
as $3.50 and undergraduates as
Much as $2.00 over the cost of
buying tickets individually. When
bought separately, tickets to the
Prom cost $4.25 on campus and
$4.50 at the door; tickets to the
Bull Roast cost $6.00 per couple;
and tickets to the Sports Dance
are also selling for $4.25 on
Campus and $4.50 at the door.

Honor Commission
Issues Reminder
For Exam Period
With final exams scheduled to
commence next week, the Honor
Commission reminds students of
their responsibility to the Honor
System, and gives the following
suggestions:
(1) In taking an exam, be
sure that, whenever possible,
there is an empty seat between
you and your neighbor.

RALPH MARTERIE

Honor Group

Picks Officers
Gordon J. Schochet was elected president of the Hopkins
chapter of,the Pi Sigma Alpha
Fraternity, national honorary in
political science, at a meeting of
the Society held early this week.
Larry M. Wolf was elected
secretary-treasurer of the organization. Both officers will
serve until the group ratifies a
constitution, "probably late in
the fall,' said Schochet.

The official installation of the
Hopkins chapter, which was organized within the past two
months, will take place this
evening at a "closed" meeting
to be held in the Hopkins FaMitgang added, "Table reser- culty Club. The installing officer
vations may be obtained at the will be Dr. W. Brooke Graves of
June Week office during lunch the Library of Congress and a
(Continued on Page 9)
hours."

Mitgang reported that tickets
Were selling a little better than
expected, but he urged that more
students buy Bull Roast tickets
now and avoid purchasing them
at the door.

(2) In order to avoid the possibility of any suspicion being
directed against you, leave all unnecessary notes and books outside the exam room.
(3) Hesitate from talking during an exam. Talking will only
cause unnecessary suspicion and
perhaps much embarassment
later on.
(4) If a violation becomes evident to you while you are taking
an exam, take it upon yourself
to remind the entire class that
we are under an Honor System.
If the apparent violation persists,
try to have someone witness the
violation" and then report it to
The Honor Commission through
the school departmental mailing system as soon as possible so
that the Honor Commission may
rapidly dispose of the case.
(5) Above all, remember that
mental frustration during an
exam, or the absence of time in
finishing a term paper is no excuse to cheat or plagiarize. Also,
bear in mind that your signature
means that the work under it is
your own, derived for credit by
honest means.

Last Issue
This is the last issue of this
year's News-letter. Thank
heavens, and all that. Have no
fears—we shall return, complete with voodoo dolls and a
healthy supply of pins.

SAC To Award Keys, Seals
To Seventy-Four At Game
By AL FIGINSKI
Associate Editor
The Student Activities ComMission's Varsity Seals and Keys
Will be presented to seventy-four
Hopkins upperclassmen tomorrow prior to the Hopkins-Mount
Washington Lacrosse game at
Homewood Field.
Also to be honored tomorrow
are nine seniors who received
the SAC key last year. These
double winners include Bill Teso
and Ron. Straka, Radio Club;
Eric Auerbach, Vector; Herb
Butler BIA and Orientation
Chairman; Porter Claxton, SAC
and Honor Commission; Don
Gallagher, H-Club and ODK;
Bob Mitgang, Booster Club;
Morris Offit, BIA; and Lew Sank,
Student Council.
Criteria For Awards
According to Lou Kady, SAC
Member, the Certificates are
awarded to members bf SAC organizations who have been active
in their respective organizations
for three years. The Keys have
the added stipulation of "exceptional services above and beYond that required of a regular
Member."
Kady stated, "We try to make
these awards an honor, not in

gross quantities. Their purpose
is to encourage entrance and
continuance of service in extracurricular activities. They are
awarded also in recognition for
a good job.
Selection Procedures
Potential award winners are
recommended to the SAC by the
executive committee of the sponsoring activity. After the recommendation, the SAC reviewed the
reports and weighed the effort
of the candidates within their
chosen activities. "In the past
all officers automatically received
awards," reported Kady, "but
this year the selection was not
automatic. ,The work of the individual was basic point of final
selection."
The awards will be made to
both seniors and juniors. "In
fact," said Kady, "we are. very
happy to see as many juniors win
Keys as possible so that they will
be worn on campus and create
interest in activities."
The fifty-one Keys will be presentqd to the following people:
Hullabaloo: Ed Seigenfeld, Dan
Sachs, Chris Kahl and Mort
Alterman.
Booster Club: Lou Kady, Larry

Kerpleman, Tony Salem and
Jack Ruffle.
Veterans Club: John Cooper,
Tom Owens, Len Stein and Bob
Wood.
WJHU: Bill Babst, Dick Bambach, and Frank Zampiello.
News-Letter: Bob Baensch,
Mal Baroway, Herb Kahler, John
Mayo-Wells,
Bob
Partridge,
Frank Young and Sid Waldron.
Band: Harold Byerly and Andy
Conn.
SDA: Ted Palmer.
Debate council: Wesley Norman, Bob Rachmalies, Al Wilner
and Larry Wolf.
Camera Club: Dick Hu; DSRC:
Bob
Hutchins; cosmopolitan
Club: Dick Hsieh; IFB: Bill
Kolomaznik; Class of 1958: Os
Steinwald; BIA: Don Petrushansky.
Cotillion Board: Charles Justis
and Ron Nagler.

and Bob Boucek.

DR. NATHAN M. PUSEY

President Milton S. Eisenhower announced on May 20
that Dr. Nathan Marsh Pusey, president of Harvard University, will deliver the commencement address at Johns
Hopkins' 81st annual graduation ceremonies on June 11.
Harvard's 24th president, Dr. Pusey is noted for his
efforts to develop the resources for undergraduate education at that institution. Last year he inaugurated an $82,500,000 expansion program, the largest undergraduate
development program in U. S. history.
Notes Financial Needs

DSRC President
Asks Residents
To Reduce Noise
Newly elected DSRC president
Jim Michael requested that all
dormitory residents take extra
precautions to keep down noise
and disturbances in the dormitory during the approaching
exam period.
"A little effort on the part of
every man can make for much
pleasanter living conditions during the next week and a half,"
stated Michael.
Last week the various entries
chose their entry representatives
to the DSRC for the coming
year. The following men were
elected: .George Krebs, Adams;
Pete Hutchinson, Baker; Phil
Rierson, Clark; Tom Shipman,
Gildersleeve; Al Plisker, Griffin;
Bob Goldstein, Hollander; Phil
John
Medenbach, Jennings;
Yang, Lazear; Dave May, Royce;
Dick Einaugler, Sylvester; and
Mike Lukens, Wilson. No election was held in Vincent House,
and Willard and Wood are graduate entries.
"I'm very, pleased with the
Council. If we can continue the
policies established this year
and do as good a job as this
year, the dorms will surely be a
better place to live," concluded
Michael.

— Honor
At a recent trial a junior
engineering student was acquitted of a violation of the
Honor Code. He was charged
with attempting to deceive the
instructor to get a postponement of ,an examination, and
thereby gaining an unfair advantage.

Recently, Dr. Pusey noted that,
"All colleges and universities that
are alive are in (financial) need."
As president of Lawrence College in Wisconsin from 1944 until
1953, when he took over the reins
at Harvard, he developed the
meager financial resources of the
college and initiated Freshman
Studies to stimulate serious reading and thinking among the new
students.
Dr. Pusey was born in Council
Bluffs, Iowa, and attended elementary and secondary schools
there. With scholarship assistance he attended Harvard,
where he received his A.B.,
magna cum laude, in 1928, his
A. M. degree in ancient history
in 1932 and his Ph.D. in 1937.
Pusey's Background
Before serving as a college
president, he taught at Scripps
College in California and Wesleyan Vniversity in Connecticut.
In addition to his university
presidential duties, Dr. Pusey is
presently serving on the Central
Committee of the World Council
of Churches and as president of
the American Association of
Theological Schools Fund, Inc.
Last year the Harvard president was named president of the
Carnegie Foundation for the
Advancement of Teaching. in
keeping with tradition, Dr. Pusey
will address the graduating
seniors at an outdoor ceremony
on Keyser Quadrangle.

Adona, Riesman
Chosen To Lead
SDA In '57-'58

Elections for the academic year
1957-58 were held this week in
the Students for Democratic Action and in the Cosmopolitan
Club.
Elected to offices in the SDA
were: Tony Adona and Mike
Riesmann, co-chairmen and Jay
Seldon, secretary-treasurer. "Appointed offices will be filled next
year," stated present chairman
Ted Palmer.

As a parting statement Claxton said, "As past chairman, I
should like to commend the students and the faculty for their
\
cooperation with the Commission
and their loyalty to the ideals of
the Honor System. The system is
only as good as the students
make it; no one group or person
can dictate a moral code.
"I sincerely feel," Claxton
added, "that our system has been
and will continue to be secured
by a strong conviction within
each individual student."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 24, 1957

NEWS -LETTER

Evening Summer Sessions
Innovated For This Year
An innovation at the Summer
Session, which begins on Monday, June 17, will be evening
classes, being held for the first
time in the 47 year history of
the Session.
Running for 9 weeks until
August 9, the evening classes
will
offer
eleven
different
courses in the following subjects:
commercial law, principles of
economics, descriptive geometry,
history of modern Europe. analytic geometry, integral calculus,
vector analysis, American national government, introductory
psychology, business and technical writing and public speaking.
According to Dean Richard A.
Mumma, "Both day and evening
courses are open to college students who have had at least
a year of successful college study.
Qualified adults who have not
attended college may also enroll." Ineligible to enroll, however, are high school students
or recent high school graduates
With no college training.

24 to August 2 will also be
offered.
Scheduled for the six-week
period will be classes in the
fields of: economics, education,
English, French, geology, geography, German, history, mathematics, music, philosophy, political science, Russian, sociology
and Spanish.
Registration Date
Registration for all eight-week
courses is scheduled for June 15
from 9 am to noon. For the sixweek courses registration will be
on June 22 from 9 am to noon.
Applications
for
admission
should be made as soon as possible: students enrolling from
other colleges or universities
must produce a "letter of good
standing" from that institution,
Dean Mumma said.

"Until I joined General Electric's Research Laboratory in 1951, I never realized science could be such
a challenge — or so much fun. My job involves research in physical chemistry — the investigation of
new ideas which can lead to new and better products..
people can use. In a company of this size, I have the

need and the experience of others close at hand. And
in return, of course, I'm expected to apply myself to

money and faith in my creative ability, and if I re-.
spond by creating, then we both benefit. To me, at
General Electric business and pleasure do mix."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 24, 1957

Collegiate Champions
•

Jays To Meet Wolfpack

For National Open Stick Title
„
By STAN HANDMAKER
Sports Editor

In a game that Coach Wilson Fewster described as
"Physically, the roughest I've seen," the smaller, but
scrappier, Blue Jays grabbed the national lacrosse championship out of the hands of the Terrapins.
Contrary to the usual, it was not the team that
controlled the ball most of the game that won. Maryland took 19 of 26 faceoff's. However, the Terps found
it very difficult to score, whereas the Jays' offense was
more affective.
Credit should go to the entire Hopkins defense, which
allowed the Terrapins only 54 shots, seven more than the
Jays. Particularly worthy of praise is Pete Banker for
his outstanding display of goal-tending.
Although they received fewer opportunities, the
Hopkins attack nevertheless proved to be the most potent
;Maryland's All-American goalie Jim Kappler ever faced,
as they gave him the worst day of his career.
It is worthy of note that the number of spectators
viewing the game from John Hopkins' side of the field
exceeded that of the home team, Maryland. For a school
so grossly lacking in spirit, Hopkins' attendance at Byrd
Stadium last Saturday evidently demonstrates the student body's willingness to back a winner. It is hoped
that the many studious and just plain indifferent -students
that crawled out of their hovels for a brief glimpse of
lacrosse will also find room in their schedules for the
other, less successful sports that are played at the Homewood.
Lacrosse Hall of Fame

A Lacrosse Hall of Fame, comparable to the National
Baseball Hall of Fame located in Cooperstown, N. Y.,
is presently being considered by a joint committee of the
Lacrosse Association and the Coaches Association.
"We're definitely interested in having Hopkins as
the site of a (Lacrosse) Hall of Fame," said Athletic Director Marshall S. Turner, Jr.
We feel that a Lacrosse Hall of Fame is a thing well
worth considering and that there could be no more fitting
a place for it than Johns Hopkins.

—Ginnis
Blue Jay stickmen Jerry Bennett (60), Bruce Duffaney (48), Dick Steele (56) and others swarm
off the bench in jubilation at the final gun of Saturday's game, signifying Hopkins' National
Championship victory over Maryland. Coach Bob Scott shows quieter joy and just pride at the
outcome. Maryland fans in the background seem less effected.

The sixteenth annual NorthSouth All-Star lacrosse game will
be played June 7 at Homewood
Field.
Coaching the South team will
be Bill Pacy of Baltimore University, assisted by Bob Sandell
of Virginia. Buzz Seymour of
Stevens Institute of Technology,
aided by Harvey Potter of Colgate, will tutor the North squad.
Each coach may choose a
maximum of three players from
each school. "I anticipate their
choosing three of our seniors
to play on the South team," said
Hopkins coach Bob Scott, general chairman of the game.
The South, winning the past
two games, has tied the series at
7-7. Last year the Rebels routed
the North, 20-10, at Hobart College in Geneva, N. Y.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, MAY 24, 1957

61ST YEAR

miEBNID

June Week Festivities Harvard's Pusey To Speak
To Close Out Year At Graduation Exercises
June Week will begin this year on Tuesday, June 4,
with the Senior Prom at the Alcazar.
The orchestra of Ralph Marlene, who won the Senior
Class poll for the Prom dance, will be featured. The dance
will be from 9-1 and set-ups will be sold, stated Mitgang.
As decided earlier in the year, the Alcazar will allow drinking at the Prom.
The Bull Roast will be held on Wednesday, June 5,
at Bowley's Resort from noon to 10 pm. Beer, bull,

bathing and the Pier Five Jazz
Band will be featured. On the
following day the Sports Dance,
headlining The Four Lads and
the Boyd Raeburn Orchestra,
Will take place at the Dixie Ballroom. The Four Lads will not
only perform during intermission, but will sing several times
during the dancing.
A formal event for seniors
only, the Senior Banquet and
Dance, will be held June 8. June
Week Chairman Bob Mitgang
said, "The Banquet will begin
at 6 P. M:and Dr. Milton Eisenhower will speak." He added,"It
Will break up in time to bring
back dates for the dancing,
Which will last from 9-1. Both
the Banquet and Dance will be
formal." Strip tickets to June Week
events are selling in Levering
Hall at $13.00 to undergraduates
and at $11.50 to seniors. By taking advantage of the strip tickets, seniors may save as much
as $3.50 and undergraduates as
Much as $2.00 over the cost of
buying tickets individually. When
bought separately, tickets to the
Prom cost $4.25 on campus and
$4.50 at the door; tickets to the
Bull Roast cost $6.00 per couple;
and tickets to the Sports Dance
are also selling for $4.25 on
Campus and $4.50 at the door.

Honor Commission
Issues Reminder
For Exam Period
With final exams scheduled to
commence next week, the Honor
Commission reminds students of
their responsibility to the Honor
System, and gives the following
suggestions:
(1) In taking an exam, be
sure that, whenever possible,
there is an empty seat between
you and your neighbor.

RALPH MARTERIE

Honor Group

Picks Officers
Gordon J. Schochet was elected president of the Hopkins
chapter of,the Pi Sigma Alpha
Fraternity, national honorary in
political science, at a meeting of
the Society held early this week.
Larry M. Wolf was elected
secretary-treasurer of the organization. Both officers will
serve until the group ratifies a
constitution, "probably late in
the fall,' said Schochet.

The official installation of the
Hopkins chapter, which was organized within the past two
months, will take place this
evening at a "closed" meeting
to be held in the Hopkins FaMitgang added, "Table reser- culty Club. The installing officer
vations may be obtained at the will be Dr. W. Brooke Graves of
June Week office during lunch the Library of Congress and a
(Continued on Page 9)
hours."

Mitgang reported that tickets
Were selling a little better than
expected, but he urged that more
students buy Bull Roast tickets
now and avoid purchasing them
at the door.

(2) In order to avoid the possibility of any suspicion being
directed against you, leave all unnecessary notes and books outside the exam room.
(3) Hesitate from talking during an exam. Talking will only
cause unnecessary suspicion and
perhaps much embarassment
later on.
(4) If a violation becomes evident to you while you are taking
an exam, take it upon yourself
to remind the entire class that
we are under an Honor System.
If the apparent violation persists,
try to have someone witness the
violation" and then report it to
The Honor Commission through
the school departmental mailing system as soon as possible so
that the Honor Commission may
rapidly dispose of the case.
(5) Above all, remember that
mental frustration during an
exam, or the absence of time in
finishing a term paper is no excuse to cheat or plagiarize. Also,
bear in mind that your signature
means that the work under it is
your own, derived for credit by
honest means.

Last Issue
This is the last issue of this
year's News-letter. Thank
heavens, and all that. Have no
fears—we shall return, complete with voodoo dolls and a
healthy supply of pins.

SAC To Award Keys, Seals
To Seventy-Four At Game
By AL FIGINSKI
Associate Editor
The Student Activities ComMission's Varsity Seals and Keys
Will be presented to seventy-four
Hopkins upperclassmen tomorrow prior to the Hopkins-Mount
Washington Lacrosse game at
Homewood Field.
Also to be honored tomorrow
are nine seniors who received
the SAC key last year. These
double winners include Bill Teso
and Ron. Straka, Radio Club;
Eric Auerbach, Vector; Herb
Butler BIA and Orientation
Chairman; Porter Claxton, SAC
and Honor Commission; Don
Gallagher, H-Club and ODK;
Bob Mitgang, Booster Club;
Morris Offit, BIA; and Lew Sank,
Student Council.
Criteria For Awards
According to Lou Kady, SAC
Member, the Certificates are
awarded to members bf SAC organizations who have been active
in their respective organizations
for three years. The Keys have
the added stipulation of "exceptional services above and beYond that required of a regular
Member."
Kady stated, "We try to make
these awards an honor, not in

gross quantities. Their purpose
is to encourage entrance and
continuance of service in extracurricular activities. They are
awarded also in recognition for
a good job.
Selection Procedures
Potential award winners are
recommended to the SAC by the
executive committee of the sponsoring activity. After the recommendation, the SAC reviewed the
reports and weighed the effort
of the candidates within their
chosen activities. "In the past
all officers automatically received
awards," reported Kady, "but
this year the selection was not
automatic. ,The work of the individual was basic point of final
selection."
The awards will be made to
both seniors and juniors. "In
fact," said Kady, "we are. very
happy to see as many juniors win
Keys as possible so that they will
be worn on campus and create
interest in activities."
The fifty-one Keys will be presentqd to the following people:
Hullabaloo: Ed Seigenfeld, Dan
Sachs, Chris Kahl and Mort
Alterman.
Booster Club: Lou Kady, Larry

Kerpleman, Tony Salem and
Jack Ruffle.

Tom Owens, Len Stein and Bob
Wood.

Mayo-Wells,

Conn.

Debate council: Wesley Norman, Bob Rachmalies, Al Wilner
and Larry Wolf.

Bob

DR. NATHAN M. PUSEY

President Milton S. Eisenhower announced on May 20
that Dr. Nathan Marsh Pusey, president of Harvard University, will deliver the commencement address at Johns
Hopkins' 81st annual graduation ceremonies on June 11.
Harvard's 24th president, Dr. Pusey is noted for his
efforts to develop the resources for undergraduate education at that institution. Last year he inaugurated an $82,500,000 expansion program, the largest undergraduate
development program in U. S. history.
Notes Financial Needs

DSRC President
Asks Residents
To Reduce Noise
Newly elected DSRC president
Jim Michael requested that all
dormitory residents take extra
precautions to keep down noise
and disturbances in the dormitory during the approaching
exam period.
"A little effort on the part of
every man can make for much
pleasanter living conditions during the next week and a half,"
stated Michael.
Last week the various entries
chose their entry representatives
to the DSRC for the coming
year. The following men were
elected: .George Krebs, Adams;
Pete Hutchinson, Baker; Phil
Rierson, Clark; Tom Shipman,
Gildersleeve; Al Plisker, Griffin;
Bob Goldstein, Hollander; Phil
John
Medenbach, Jennings;
Yang, Lazear; Dave May, Royce;
Dick Einaugler, Sylvester; and
Mike Lukens, Wilson. No election was held in Vincent House,
and Willard and Wood are graduate entries.
"I'm very, pleased with the
Council. If we can continue the
policies established this year
and do as good a job as this
year, the dorms will surely be a
better place to live," concluded
Michael.

— Honor
At a recent trial a junior
engineering student was acquitted of a violation of the
Honor Code. He was charged
with attempting to deceive the
instructor to get a postponement of ,an examination, and
thereby gaining an unfair advantage.

Recently, Dr. Pusey noted that,
"All colleges and universities that
are alive are in (financial) need."
As president of Lawrence College in Wisconsin from 1944 until
1953, when he took over the reins
at Harvard, he developed the
meager financial resources of the
college and initiated Freshman
Studies to stimulate serious reading and thinking among the new
students.
Dr. Pusey was born in Council
Bluffs, Iowa, and attended elementary and secondary schools
there. With scholarship assistance he attended Harvard,
where he received his A.B.,
magna cum laude, in 1928, his
A. M. degree in ancient history
in 1932 and his Ph.D. in 1937.
Pusey's Background
Before serving as a college
president, he taught at Scripps
College in California and Wesleyan Vniversity in Connecticut.
In addition to his university
presidential duties, Dr. Pusey is
presently serving on the Central
Committee of the World Council
of Churches and as president of
the American Association of
Theological Schools Fund, Inc.
Last year the Harvard president was named president of the
Carnegie Foundation for the
Advancement of Teaching. in
keeping with tradition, Dr. Pusey
will address the graduating
seniors at an outdoor ceremony
on Keyser Quadrangle.

Evening Summer Sessions
Innovated For This Year
An innovation at the Summer
Session, which begins on Monday, June 17, will be evening
classes, being held for the first
time in the 47 year history of
the Session.
Running for 9 weeks until
August 9, the evening classes
will
offer
eleven
different
courses in the following subjects:
commercial law, principles of
economics, descriptive geometry,
history of modern Europe. analytic geometry, integral calculus,
vector analysis, American national government, introductory
psychology, business and technical writing and public speaking.
According to Dean Richard A.
Mumma, "Both day and evening
courses are open to college students who have had at least
a year of successful college study.
Qualified adults who have not
attended college may also enroll." Ineligible to enroll, however, are high school students
or recent high school graduates
With no college training.

24 to August 2 will also be
offered.
Scheduled for the six-week
period will be classes in the
fields of: economics, education,
English, French, geology, geography, German, history, mathematics, music, philosophy, political science, Russian, sociology
and Spanish.
Registration Date
Registration for all eight-week
courses is scheduled for June 15
from 9 am to noon. For the sixweek courses registration will be
on June 22 from 9 am to noon.
Applications
for
admission
should be made as soon as possible: students enrolling from
other colleges or universities
must produce a "letter of good
standing" from that institution,
Dean Mumma said.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 24, 1957

Correspondence
Editors:
.While rummaging through the
stacks in Gilman I noticed a
sheet of weathered parchment on
.the floor. I picked it up and noted that while it was written in
a very obscure language that
someone had pencilled a translation of the paper between the
lines in English. Here is the
story:
Once upon a time there was
a
small country known as Miltonia.
He was a good, sincere king, but
he had other interests than his

a king, Milton of Ike, who ruled

kingdom.
The country had its army, and
It came to pass that after many
Years of defeat, the army, bolstered by new heroes, one of
Whom was the son of one of the
King's lords, won many battles
in their yearly war.
There was one more battle to
be fought. The adversary was the
neighboring kingdom of Terpia,
very powerful, and with a very
strong army that had won its
last thirty-one battles. With the
winning of this battle the army
of Miltonia would win the war,
bringing victory to Miltonia for
the first time in many years.
Most of the King's lords travelled
the many miles to the battlefield, and his subjects, in a
frenzy over the prospect of victory, jammed into carts, and
raced across the countryside to
view the spectacle.
But the King himself was not
to be seen. He had abandoned
his army, and instead of supporting them by his presence at the

battle he surreptitiously attended the jousts that day. His army,
even without their leader won
the battle, and vanquished Terpia. His people, however, learning of his whereabouts during the
fighting, and even some of his
lords, were horrified, so . ..
I tried to find the second page
of the narrative, but after a long,
fruitless search, gave up. But
one man who is very learned

NEWS -LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 24, 1957

Collegiate Champions
•

Jays To Meet Wolfpack

For National Open Stick Title
„
By STAN HANDMAKER
Sports Editor

In a game that Coach Wilson Fewster described as
"Physically, the roughest I've seen," the smaller, but
scrappier, Blue Jays grabbed the national lacrosse championship out of the hands of the Terrapins.
Contrary to the usual, it was not the team that
controlled the ball most of the game that won. Maryland took 19 of 26 faceoff's. However, the Terps found
it very difficult to score, whereas the Jays' offense was
more affective.
Credit should go to the entire Hopkins defense, which
allowed the Terrapins only 54 shots, seven more than the
Jays. Particularly worthy of praise is Pete Banker for
his outstanding display of goal-tending.
Although they received fewer opportunities, the
Hopkins attack nevertheless proved to be the most potent
;Maryland's All-American goalie Jim Kappler ever faced,
as they gave him the worst day of his career.
It is worthy of note that the number of spectators
viewing the game from John Hopkins' side of the field
exceeded that of the home team, Maryland. For a school
so grossly lacking in spirit, Hopkins' attendance at Byrd
Stadium last Saturday evidently demonstrates the student body's willingness to back a winner. It is hoped
that the many studious and just plain indifferent -students
that crawled out of their hovels for a brief glimpse of
lacrosse will also find room in their schedules for the
other, less successful sports that are played at the Homewood.
Lacrosse Hall of Fame

A Lacrosse Hall of Fame, comparable to the National
Baseball Hall of Fame located in Cooperstown, N. Y.,
is presently being considered by a joint committee of the
Lacrosse Association and the Coaches Association.
"We're definitely interested in having Hopkins as
the site of a (Lacrosse) Hall of Fame," said Athletic Director Marshall S. Turner, Jr.
We feel that a Lacrosse Hall of Fame is a thing well
worth considering and that there could be no more fitting
a place for it than Johns Hopkins.

—Ginnis

off the bench in jubilation at the final gun of Saturday's game, signifying Hopkins' National
Championship victory over Maryland. Coach Bob Scott shows quieter joy and just pride at the
outcome. Maryland fans in the background seem less effected.

The sixteenth annual NorthSouth All-Star lacrosse game will
be played June 7 at Homewood
Field.
Coaching the South team will
be Bill Pacy of Baltimore University, assisted by Bob Sandell
of Virginia. Buzz Seymour of
Stevens Institute of Technology,
aided by Harvey Potter of Colgate, will tutor the North squad.
Each coach may choose a
maximum of three players from
each school. "I anticipate their
choosing three of our seniors
to play on the South team," said
Hopkins coach Bob Scott, general chairman of the game.
The South, winning the past
two games, has tied the series at
7-7. Last year the Rebels routed
the North, 20-10, at Hobart College in Geneva, N. Y.

Pi Delta Epsilon, honorary journalism fraternity, has announced
that the annual picnic will be
held tonight at the usual haunt,
the bottom of Bottom Road.
"We have wasted thousands
of dollars upon taste-tempting
delicacies," said Rothney,"which
include twenty cases of chocolate-covered kreplach, and seventeen tins of pistachio caviar."
Rothney announced that, in
keeping with tradition, a King
of the Mountain contest will be
held, the victorious contestant
to be the recipient of one case of
the Hebraic "won-ton."

Mayo-Wells, who last year was
defeated by Rothney in both this
escapade and the "duck for the
ravioli" contest, has stated firmly that he will emerge victorious
this year. "Last year," he said,
"I emerged bloody but unbowed.
This time the Rothney empire
shall topple."
Pi D E secretary-treasurer Sid
Waldron told the new initiates
that they are free to bring dates,
but, he warned "they better
know how ,to take care of themselves. We are gentlemen of

Ron Nagler was elected president, Howie Richter vice-president, and Malcolm Kitt secretary
of the YMCA Cabinet at a meeting held last Friday. The cabinet
has yet to add six members to
its ranks.
Also, Tom Owens, Joel Woodey,
and Joe Kaplan received keys
for outstanding service in the
YMCA at the recent Parents'
Day Banquet, said Executive
Secretary Chester L. Wickwire.
The awards "are being given
for special service to the YMCA
and the campus," said Wickwire.
Owens is the recent President
of the YMCA student cabinet.
Woodey was membership chairman in 1955-56, and Kaplan was

Hullabaloo Press Date Set;
DedicationTo illiamBain
"The Hullabaloo will go to
press June 26, and barring unforeseen difficulties, should be
out the second week of August,"
said Ed Seigenfeld, Hullabaloo
editor, adding "we anticipate a
very good book this year."
Seniors will be mailed copies
of the book as soon as they are
printed. "The price may have to
be raised," Seigenfeld commented, explaining that attempts
are being made to keep it at $6.50
as last year.

campus," said Seigenfeld. The
book will not be divided into the
four seasons as in the past, but
will be divided into sections for
classes, fraternities, honoraries,
sports, activities, and ROTC.
The 256-page book will be
dedicated to the late editor-inchief, Bill Bain, and will begin
with a 2-page color spread
photograph of the campus.
